posts.name: Grant Spadafore
posts.cooked:
I have been trying to get some ThriftyCams our team purchased to work via manual exposure control for a few weeks now. Nothing I’ve done has disabled auto exposure, and it seems they might not support ANY UVC-configs. How can these cameras be used in an on-field environment for Apriltag detection without manual exposure control? I have tried the following:

Connecting to them over Photon Vision (being sure to use a USB 3 port), and attempting to turn off auto exposure, and set exposure values. Doing such only gave an exposure range (in the PhotonVision UI webpage) of -1 to -10, suggesting that it couldn’t do anything. When I set it to -1, -10, or any value in between, the output didn’t change, and pointing it at a light still obviously was using auto exposure.

Connecting to them over Photon Vision (being sure to use a USB 3 port), and attempting to turn off auto exposure, and set exposure values. Doing such only gave an exposure range (in the PhotonVision UI webpage) of -1 to -10, suggesting that it couldn’t do anything. When I set it to -1, -10, or any value in between, the output didn’t change, and pointing it at a light still obviously was using auto exposure.

Connecting over a Windows computer, again a USB 3 supported cable, and using the built in camera app to set exposure. Doing this only allowed for brightness control, which was entirely brightening/darkening (in post) the image, not disabling auto-exposure. As a confirmation that the application supports exposure control, I plugged in my personal webcam, which allowed for the disabling of auto exposure.

Connecting over a Windows computer, again a USB 3 supported cable, and using the built in camera app to set exposure. Doing this only allowed for brightness control, which was entirely brightening/darkening (in post) the image, not disabling auto-exposure. As a confirmation that the application supports exposure control, I plugged in my personal webcam, which allowed for the disabling of auto exposure.

Connecting over a Linux distro, namely Debian Bookworm, and using a camera application. It too, had the same outputs as Windows, that being brightness control in post, and no control over anything else.

Connecting over a Linux distro, namely Debian Bookworm, and using a camera application. It too, had the same outputs as Windows, that being brightness control in post, and no control over anything else.

Connecting over a MacOS device, namely a Macbook, and using a quickly written python script to attempt to set their exposure values using Cv2/AVFoundation. Here, while no output changes occured, I did see that via AVFoundation’s ExposureModes , it said it only supported AVCaptureExposureModeLocked and AVCaptureExposureModeContinuousAutoExposure . I was unable to set these to custom, which would allow me to edit exposure values/disable auto exposure. No luck here.

Connecting over a MacOS device, namely a Macbook, and using a quickly written python script to attempt to set their exposure values using Cv2/AVFoundation. Here, while no output changes occured, I did see that via AVFoundation’s ExposureModes , it said it only supported AVCaptureExposureModeLocked and AVCaptureExposureModeContinuousAutoExposure . I was unable to set these to custom, which would allow me to edit exposure values/disable auto exposure. No luck here.

I’m at my wits end with these cameras. Theres no way that Thrifty would forget to support manual exposure, right? Apriltag detection suffers heavily, in our testing with these cameras, when you have auto exposure, as when the scenery changes, it loses tracking of the apriltags for a short time–even with global shutter. Has anyone gotten them to be manual exposure?

posts.name: Craig Schardt
posts.cooked:
Eaglegrant:

Connecting to them over Photon Vision (being sure to use a USB 3 port), and attempting to turn off auto exposure, and set exposure values. Doing such only gave an exposure range (in the PhotonVision UI webpage) of -1 to -10, suggesting that it couldn’t do anything. When I set it to -1, -10, or any value in between, the output didn’t change, and pointing it at a light still obviously was using auto exposure.

Please open an issue on the PhotonVision GitHub and post logs.

posts.name: Grant Spadafore
posts.cooked:
I’m not trying to run these on Photon Vision is the only problem, I was just using it as a test of “these cameras work… right”?

These are the logs, but I was just wondering if anyone has gotten these cameras to work somehow with iso/exposure control, which I expect should be present given they’re FRC cameras.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Which version of PV were you using?

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Can you try the latest dev release?

posts.name: billbo911
posts.cooked:
Since these are fully UVC compliant, you “should” be able to access manual exposure control via v4l2.

Start with:

List all video device’s controls and their values: v4l2-ctl [ -l | --list-ctrls ] [ -d | --device ] path/to/video_device

This will list available controls. With that info you should be able to find out how to put it into manual exposure.

I have more detailed info at home. Please ask if you need them. I’ll follow up later today.

posts.name: Grant Spadafore
posts.cooked:
So I didn’t do that exactly since I’m on Windows, but I did something similar on Windows. FINALLY, a way to control the exposure of these cameras. However, when I was testing the camera via Window’s

ffmpeg -f dshow -show_video_device_dialog true -i video="PC Camera"

I was also able to edit not only the exposure, but also the saturation… Turning that up gave me this. I still had full 60fps…

My only remaining question is how I can actually access these properties via a python script, as using Cv2’s implementation doesn’t work, it outputs nothing. Is there a way I could run it on MacOS? I’m trying to do something akin to 6328’s Northstar solution, but I require exposure control through Mac, needing the name of the properties of whatever Windows is using.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked:
Use a subprocess.

Wait sorry, that wouldn’t work on Mac.
